So the title of this essay is Double Bill, The Music of the Next Karate Kid.
In 1994, decades before the act of gender swapping, a property became de rigueur in Hollywood.
An enormously successful movie franchise rolled the dice by trading out its titular male hero for a tough female lead.
The series in question was Columbia Pictures' The Karate Kid, the first of which became a sleeper hit in the summer of 1984.
At the heart of the original movie was a bond between a bullied boy, Daniel LaRusso, Ralph Macchio,
and his benevolent karate teacher, Mr. Miyagi, Noriyuku Pat Morita.
Through a series of lessons, both physical and spiritual,
Miyagi helps Daniel achieve the balance to both defend himself and win the girl.
The appeal of these characters turned the film into a cultural touchstone
with a box office take of $91 million.
Two financially successful sequels and a cartoon series followed.
But by the end of 1989's The Karate Kid Part III,
the relationship between LaRusso and Miyagi had seemingly run its course,
and series screenwriter Robert Mark Kamen
felt that there was little more he could say with these characters.
Additionally, Ralph Macchio, who was 23 during the filming of the original, was now 30 years old, and his believability as a teenaged protagonist had worn thin.

The franchise lay dormant for five years until Columbia Pictures decided to revisit the property and determine if the formula could prosper once more, this time with a female pupil, the next karate kid in Daniel's stead.
While Marina was game for one more outing as Miyagi,
Kamen had been disappointed that his original idea for Part 3 was turned down.
His pitch was to be a prequel that centered on one of Miyagi's 16th-century ancestors,
who ironically was also to be female.
With Kamen bowing out, a relatively untested screenwriter, Mark Lee,
1994's Fortunes of War, was brought on to script the new film.

Also joining the franchise with director Christopher Kane, who had a hit with Young Guns, 1988, and who's the principal, 1987, made him a potentially solid match for the next Karate Kid subject matter with its hostile high school setting.

Miyagi is first seen attending a commendation for his service in the legendary 442nd Regimental Combat Team during World War II.
There, he reconnects with Louisa, Constance Towers, the widow of his commanding officer and friend, Jack Pierce.
Miyagi learns that the couple's granddaughter, Julie, is suffering with anger issues over the recent loss of her parents, who died in a car crash.
At school, Julie begins to kindle a relationship with a well-meaning classmate, Eric, Chris Conrad.

a fraternity of thugs who were enabled by their sadistic teacher, Colonel Dugan, Michael Ironside, in the Martin Cove, John Kreese-style role.
